issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2) incorrectly says "Each method takes a Consumer<List<Note>> parameter" while the template and intended implementation use Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods. This is a copy-paste/text inconsistency that can confuse students about the correct generic type they should use when implementing the client-side PersonController methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods so it matches the template method signatures and the intended solution. For clarity, ensure the paragraph explicitly states that each PersonController method accepts a Consumer<List<Person>> which will be invoked with the controller's internal list of Person objects after a response is received.

issues.description: The problem statement (Part 2 description) incorrectly refers to the callback parameter type as Consumer<List<Note>> when describing the PersonController methods. The template and solution implementations use Consumer<List<Person>> for the PersonController methods. This mismatch (Note vs Person) is a naming inconsistency that can confuse students about the expected type and mapping for the Person-related controller methods.
issues.suggested_fix: Update the problem statement text to refer to Consumer<List<Person>> (not Consumer<List<Note>>) when describing the PersonController methods and their callback parameter. This aligns the prose with the template and solution method signatures and avoids student confusion.
